comments.text:
Just want to say now: it's incredibly fucking expensive to live in major 
cities or prefectures, Tokyo namely. And if you don't have a great immune 
system, you're likely going to catch a lot of colds and a flu or two when 
you arrive there within the first month or two-- you'll probably keep 
adjusting for the next 3-5 months. Fish and rice are probably the main two 
foods eaten there, and anything imported from your country is going to be 
almost un-purchasable for how much money it'll cost. I'm just telling you 
right now.

If you move to a city, it wont be so bad, but living out in the country, 
you'd probably be an anomaly if you don't have close blood-related Asian 
ancestry(a grandmother or parent, for instance). So, be comfortable with 
stares and questions. Though, honestly, this can happen anywhere if you 
look a lot different than the natives.

Strong work ethic, too. Don't be lazy. And they still treat people as 
weirdo's if they're obsessive about anime or manga like it "too" much. Just 
like most of your peers probably do. Anime makes it look idyllic, but 
honestly, make sure you do your research before you plan to move to a 
different country with very different laws, social rules/etiquette, and 
culture. It can be a great place to live, but know your stuff.

top_comment.author: Strattex

comments.text:
While we often refer to anime as japanese, there have been other "chinese" 
or 'korean" anime as well. So much so that if you weren't told beforehand, 
you would never be able to discern where each was from. That being said, if 
an american man went to japan to make cartoons, does that mean it's anime? 
If a japanese man went to america (fuck it, the UK) to draw/animate, does 
that mean it's not anime? Anime as we know it has a distinct style (one 
that distances it from other more "american" cartoons) yes, but it by no 
means belongs to a country. That's about as pretentious as saying that 
maple syrup is only considered actual maple syrup if it was made in Canada
comments.author: Frost Archer

comments.text:
I prefer subs myself because there are a number of nuances that are lost in 
translation.
Then there are the numerous dubbed anime tend to take female characters 
with generally mellow voices and give them these shrieking death voices 
that make me physically cringe.
Besides that, I can understand a lot of the common phrases already (from 
watching so much), so I only need to read the subtitles for long 
explanations usually, so it's not a hassle to watch the subs like it is for 
a lot of people who prefer the dubs.
Oh, and the subs tend to come out 1-4 years before the dubs. There's that 
too.

comments.author: oathization

comments.text:
+Rune I will admit that, yes some things are inevitably lost in translation 
but that is to be expected when traversing from one language to the other. 
It's called working around an untranslatable word, even subtitles do this. 
Japan does this as well with american shows/movies. God knows how many 
changes they make to the lyrics of disney songs. Or how many pop culture 
references they remove/alter. But you know what, just because the lyrics of 
a song are slightly different, or a joke is dropped or altered, doesn't 
affect the plot in any significant way.

this brings us to your point about missing plotlines. which is flat out 
wrong on like 90% of all english dubbed works (the 10% being 4kids and 
pre-90s dubs). Most legit dubbing companies try to stay as close as they 
can to the source material as possible rarely leaving anything out. The 
dialogue may not be word for word, but as I said earlier, the meaning is 
kept the same and the plot is not altered in any significant way. Hell, 
sometimes, even subtitles aren't always the exact same depending on who's 
doing the translating.

There are numerous anime that have well done english voice casts (Hellsing, 
Baccano, FMA, and Black Lagoon just to name a few) I would even go so far 
as to say that numerous dubs have surpassed their sub counterparts.  If you 
prefer the sub version over the dub, that's fine, I'm completely okay with 
that. But to declare ALL english dub works as "inferior" to their sub 
counterparts simply due to  them not being in the original language or due 
to missing out on a few word puns is completely asinine.
comments.author: Reaper00140

comments.author: Cindy Vuu

comments.text:
+Aaron Medberry Honestly like other people said, it's what you feel like 
watching. Sometimes with some anime I feel as if the English is soooo much 
funnier than the Japanese, but with a show like Attack on Titan, everything 
sounds WAY too Americanized where the story that takes place doesn't exist 
as dubbed. The Japanese voice actors convey a LOT more emotion than the 
English voice actors, so I end up feeling a sense of empowerment and all 
the emotion that is originally conveyed. With the English, I feel it is 
lost within the translations. With the Japanese I feel as if I could 
connect with the characters every time I'd watch something from it. I 
rewatched most of the series in English and felt myself getting annoyed as 
I found the characters' English voices being annoying and non-fitting to 
the character.

But anywho, to each his own. If you're not a fan for subbed I'd say go for 
dubbed, but if you don't care like me then you should definitely go for 
dubbed. It's all the matter of your opinion and that's what counts!
comments.author: Lethalnewb

comments.text:
+Firestorm436 I understand if you find it silly and I don't have anything 
against you for it. Everyone is entitled to their own opinion about things. 
I see why you find it silly though. But as for your opinion on Japan, I 
never knew they did tentacle porn and I also don't know what that is but am 
not trying to find out. I always look and the educated side of Japan. Like 
how they invented things such as the Vocaliod squad which is a group of 
animated characters that sing as if they were real people in real time. 
They have concerts all over Japan. Watch the video elders react to 
Vocaliods if you don't know what I'm talking about. But yeah, I find it 
okay if you think what you think.
comments.author: Carenne Etienne

comments.text:
+Carenne Etienne First off. If you're a preteen that's a more educated 
answer than i've heard from some older people, but as for Anime. I just 
find it..silly? I've tried to watch some serious ( Black Butler, Attack on 
Titan, Full metal Alchemist), and I got easily disinterested. As for Japan. 
It's weird that their culture has changed from the strong sense of honor 
such as in WWII. To tentacle porn and animated shows. I just find it 
strange.
comments.author: Firestorm436

comments.text:
+Firestorm436 Yes I watch anime almost everyday. Anime is the ONLY 
animation type that can combine emotion, humor, and so many other human 
feelings. If you compare certain cartoons to anime you'll find it that 
anime will make you laugh harder, cry harder, and just wonder more. To 
answer your last question, you can't just judge a country by what you 
generally hear about it or see from it. Believe it or not, Japan is a 
country that is much more dedicated to education that most countries. 
That's one of the reasons why most Japanese people are smart or at least 
capable of thinking in ways that are different from how others would 
generally think. I honestly admire Japan and how they try to push 
themselves to do certain things. I hop i answered your questions and I'm 
sorry for writing so much and sounding like some complicated adult. I'm 
still a preteen by the way. ;D
comments.author: Carenne Etienne

SAO's a piece of crap. A piece of crap that I enjoyed for some reason. It 
is objectively bad though. Blue Exorcist is forgettable, I do think Soul 
Eater was genuinely good though. SnK/AoT has a forgettable story—it's 
concept is really good though, not original: good. It also has, in most 
people's opinions, really good animation, and really good music. That's why 
it's popular. I think it's also right on to border of not serious at all 
and taking itself too seriously, which makes it watchable.

comments.text:
+MelficeN7 The show had great potential and it squandered it all. SAO got 
really episodic with every episode Kirito meets a new girl and they fall in 
love with him. And then there was Asuna who had potential to a great 
character only to turn into a love sick idiot. Speaking of love the show 
developed a huge romantic plot tumor. Why we needed to turn the show into a 
lame love story? I have no idea. Gave up half way through and read the 
summary online to see if it got any better. It didn't, so I dropped it. I 
can't believe how many people like this show. I expected a lot better than 
what I got. And the first half was not that great either. I sat there 
waiting to be amazed, and nothing happened.
You are being kind to call it mediocre. This was by no means well written. 
It was a great concept though. Like to see it used in the future with a 
stronger writer.

comments.text:
"[Anime] is for all ages." Meaning, as he said just before that, Cartoons, 
here, is viewed as something for kids to watch. And even though Anime 
(derived from the English word animation) is the same medium, it is not 
restricted to one demographic. Anime is just the same as any show, except 
it's animated. Live-action shows is just the popular medium here, as anime 
is in Japan. +Blo0dredRidingHo0d is right, yeah. I just wanted to give the 
more detailed explanation XD Like, there *are* specific genres to separate 
the anime (and manga). "Shoujo," means "young girl," and therefore the 
demographic is for younger females. Conversely, "shounen," means "young 
boy," and the demographic is younger males. "Josei" and "Seinen" are then 
older female and older male, respectively. Yeap :v

ängstlich ist usw. ist ja eigentlich auch ein wenig subjektiv. :) Trotzdem 
hast du andere gute Begründungen gebracht und dadurch kann ich, vor allem 
an deiner Stelle, schon verstehen, dass Leute Mirai Nikki nicht mögen. Vor 
allem eben durch den ängstlichen Yuki^^ Mir ist bewusst dass er der

finde wir sollten an dieser Stelle mal so langsam mit der Diskussion 
aufhören... das Ganze ist nämlich auf Dauer, finde ich, ziemlich sinnlos 
und ist eigentlich nur ein ständiges Hin- und Her zwischen "Mirai Nikki ist 
schlecht" und "Mirai Nikki ist gut"^^ Einigen wir uns doch einfach darauf, 
dass Animes toll sind und es ebenfalls toll ist ein Otaku zu sein. :)

comments.author: Dark Gunman

comments.text:
+Dark Gunman
Because it was vitally important.

Kaneki seemed weak, despite us KNOWING he was MUCH stronger due to seeing 
flashes of it when he was let himself get blinded by hunger/pain and 
dulling his moral/ethical concerns, and became afraid of using his kagune, 
especially following the Yomo incident, and decided to learn to fight 
without relying on his kagune which he did for about 3-4 months solid 
between the end of the dove arc and the gourmet arc.

The biggest change was during Jason's torture he realized that holding back 
was stupid and unless he was willing to take risks and make hard 
choices/sacrifices, he wouldn't be able to protect anyone. His mother being 
important, because it was her reluctance to tell her mooch sister to go die 
in a ditch that ended up working her to death, just like Kaneki's 
reluctance to give his all against Jason directly resulted in the deaths of 
the 2 ghouls.

(Not to mention all the torture Jason had done to him had dulled his 
ability to feel pain and given him a thorough understand of what his body 
could actually take and used that to his advantage in his fight. Of course 
it helped that Rize was simply a stronger ghoul then Jason (though both 
were rated as S class), so Kaneki already had an advantage in terms of raw 
power and finally had the resolve to use that strength without reservation).

Biting Jason had zero to do with the fight (aside for causing him to freak 
out because he didn't think that the, up to that point, mentally broken 
Kaneki had any fight left in him), until the end where he literally ate on 
of his Kakuhou to stop his regeneration.
comments.author: ZanathKariashi

comments.text:

That would be fine, except that he
1: He was showed just 1 time fighting and training. But he bite him and 
WOW! HE IS STRONGER THAN EVER. Wich leads me to
2: why bring up about his mother? The autor expressed during the first 2 
arcs how is he (emo) Whtas the need to bring childs traumas? HE IS 
SUFFERING TORTURE!

comments.text:
Well the deal kinda is a personal preference. I would watch Code Geass, 
Gundam 00, and Cowboy Bebop dubbed. I would even watch Ruroni Kenshin 
dubbed. However there are also series that just have a better sub cast to 
fit the character in my mind. For example Eden of the East has a great 
English cast. The Japanese cast is alright. Spice and Wolf and Wolf 
Children both have great dub and sub casts. However in that instance I 
would rather watch it in English than Japanese because 1) I have watched 
them so many times and 2) It doesnt affect the story at all. 

Also if you dont speak Japanese or understand a little vocabulary or are 
trying to learn Japanese a Japanese dub does nothing for you because the 
voice actors sound just as weird in Japanese as they do in English. You 
just dont speak Japanese and dont understand what they are saying so it all 
sounds good.
comments.author: Christian Gotsch

comments.text:
+deserada There will always be sub-par dubs out there, and while it is 
difficult to completely replicate the original actors performance, it's not 
exactly fair to write off all dubs as unfaithful, considering many people 
in the localisation industry now are anime buffs themselves, who will study 
the anime they have to dub thoroughly, and try their best to hire actors 
who can empathise with the respective character and stories themselves.
comments.author: Rosa Viva

comments.text:
+Taylor Simounet
Exactly. I also think that the English dub voices don't fit the character's 
looks and personality, but that's just my opinion of the few dubs I've 
watched. I don't like it when in the dubbed versions, they add in extra 
sounds and speak when there is supposed to be silence. Like in Spirited 
Away. It's like they don't think we're smart enough to deduce what's going 
on, it all has to be explicitly stated.
comments.author: mmzaang33

comments.text:
+Rosa Viva It's not as though poorly dubbed series suddenly cease to be a 
problem. Knowing that the probability of a re-dub is near impossible, there 
is good reason to become accustomed to subtitles.

Furthermore, the creators of an adaptation are those who directly hire 
their voice cast, whereas the localization team hires a voice cast in their 
stead, adding to the deviation. By way of logic, a localized dub cannot 
possibly be as or more faithful to the source material as the native 
adaptation.
comments.author: deserada

comments.text: +Muhammad Kharismawan not true. But that's opinion
comments.author: Nipah EveryDay

comments.text:

happen. I just can't get the emotion... Shows how hard a Seiyuu's work are
comments.author: Muhammad Kharismawan

comments.text:

anymore. It's old news. It isn't the same as ten years ago. Most dubs done

material they dub. The censorship of anime is no where near as prominent 
nowadays.

comments.text:
+thehelmet boy You can watch Hunter x Huner 2011 you don't have to watch 
anything else I think it's a remake and not sequel. My recomendations for 
you would be:
Eureka Seven - a bit long mecha/action/romance
Mirai Nikki - a bit strange it has plenty of brutality and it's fantasy
Gintama - I don't think you would enjoy it now, but maybe after you watched 
some more animes. It's a very funny comedy but at the same time it has some 
epic battles and is pretty serious at some points. It has small arcs and no 
fourth wall whatsoever they just break it at the start and leave it like 
that :D.
Soul Eater - comedy and cool battles
Durarara!! - it's pretty random at times it has some fantasy and it's a 
mystery
If you want more info about an anime you can look it up in MAL. Also you 
can find new animes there, it's pretty usefull if don't know it already.

Hey, beautydreamer -- if you like shoujo, Natsuiro Kiseki is surprisingly 
good in my book. If you're not picky about what kind of animation is 
involved, you could check out RoosterTeeth's RWBY, a light-hearted

fight scenes are spectacular.
comments.author: ArticulateDuck

comments.text:
+MlpGravityFalls-Fan Eh, the characters lack depth, the plot twists are 
contrived, and the creators seemed more focused on borrowing as many 
disparate attributes of MMORPGs and online play as they could, rather than 
creating a cohesive narrative.

The second season was just strung on because the first was successful, and 
failed to strike the same emotional chords as the first, trying to make up 
for it by being darker and edgier in some ways, but really just ended up 
stumbling its way over themes discussed far more masterfully in No Game No 
Life, and largely relying on the first season's momentum to carry it 
through. It didn't maintain the tension of the first one, which was 
honestly one of its few strengths. I just wasn't too impressed by SAO.
comments.author: ArticulateDuck

comments.text:
There are good english dubs/VA's out there (Krispin Freeman anyone?), 
they're just too few too far apart. Sooner or later you're gonna run into a 
great show that gets raped by the dub, and that's where I put down the boot 
and go "ok, only dubs for me".

I'm danish and I loved Star Wars back in its day (y'know 4,5 and 6), 
imagine me going "bah, can't be arsed to read the subtitles, I'm waiting 
for the dub (which ofc never happened)". It's just a guess but I gather the 
amount of good VA's in Denmark in relation to US is about the same as the 
US in relation to Japan, that's to say nowhere near :)

comments.text:
+Damian Cruz I shall tell you anywayz! 
No, Mei Misaki is not dead. You see, there is a 'curse' type thing in the 
class. I won't go into to much detail, but basically one person every month 
dies. This doesn't happen every year because they found a way to stop it. 
They realised that the cause of this was when there was an extra person in 
the class (This isn't the main character, it is someone who died but 
doesn't know it. Just accept the fact that they are dead). The way to stop 
is is to pretend that someone in the class doesn't exist, they chose Mei. 
Mei Misaki lost her eye to a tumour when she was 4. Her mother said that 
fake eyes are ugly, so she gave her a dolls eye. For supernatural reasons 
that add more plot to the show further on, she can see things that no one 
else can through this dolls eye. So she keeps it patched up mostly.

Totally. I'd watch available dubs as long as the voice acting wasn't bad.
If I can actually understand what people are saying I can pay more 
attention to the visuals and/or sound effects (ironically?) or I can do 
other things that require little mental power but force me to look away 
from the screen like eating dinner or jotting down notes for my D&D 
campaign as I steal plots.

HULU used to allow searching for anime' with dubs but got rid of that a 
long time ago. I actually end up watching less because I don't want to sit 
through a commercial only to find I can't multitask while watching.

comments.text:
+Dynakirby63 I don't know about the BEST dub, but I definitely agree that 
it's very well done. I can't for the life of me understand why people care 
so much about sub vs dub; as long as an accurate representation of what's 
supposed to be going on is displayed, I really don't mind. Attack on 
Titan's dub is fairly true to the original, that's what really matters. 
And if we really wanna throw a hissy fit about which one is the "original", 
neither subs nor dubs are exactly the original experience. The original 
experience would be knowing the Japanese language and watching it with no 
subtitles. In fact, some may argue that taking in the visuals completely 
without averting attention to subtitles by watching a dub is closer to the 
true experience, but I don't know if I'd personally go that direction 
because, if both subs and dubs are well done, they're both equal in my 
eyes. Maybe I'm just saying this because I've just recently started getting 
into anime, but... I really don't see what the big deal is. Just let people 
choose what they want to watch. If a sub-watcher can have a proper 
conversation with a dub-watcher regarding the show's plot, then I'd say the 
dubbers and subbers did their job just fine.

It depends. If your looking for something that's fun to watch and doesn't 
require much thought, then it's fairly decent. Just turn off your brain and 
enjoy the ride.
If you care about a good story however, Then it's detrimental. Any gamer 
would say that a good game is determined from the gameplay, not from its 
graphics. The same is true for shows and anime. It doesn't matter how 
amazing the show looks, if the characters are one-dimensional and bland, 
the story will fail and crumble.
comments.author: xLOKIx0830

comments.text:
isn't that a bad thing when the animation and settings become the show and 
the characters are not interesting ?
comments.author: heloves23

comments.text:
+heloves23
Not even close. All the people who die are either background characters you 
have only seen for 30 seconds, or are one-dimensional, uninteresting 
characters who you don't care die or don't even remember who they were when 
they die. All the main characters are immortal with plot armor.

If you watch Attack on Titan, you'll enjoy it for the survival setting it 
has and the absolutely stellar visuals and animation, not for the story or 
the character...definitely not the characters.
comments.author: xLOKIx0830

comments.text:
+heloves23 More or less, but at some point it's easy to figure out who is 
likely to die anytime soon. Game of Thrones has a tendency to kill people 
off without much warning, Attack on Titan not so much in the later parts of 
the series.
comments.author: TheMikarin of Pierrot

comments.text: so basically it's Game of Thrones in anime style?
comments.author: heloves23

comments.text:

both Game of Thrones and The Walking Dead.

It seems that TWD, GOT, AND AOT have a working formula, so all inspiring 
writers, just kill all your characters for a good show.

+imawinner21 Well... Cartoon means anime in Japanese. If something is 
animated in 'anime' style in America then its a cartoon even though it 
looks like an anime its not. But if in Japan an animation is in 'cartoon' 
style its still an anime. Btw I read this somewhere and if I'm wrong tell 
because I'm not sure if I'm right.
comments.author: spacenoke

comments.text:
Anime is a made up word. Presumably (but not officially) a creation of 
Warner Brothers company, with the idea to discriminate and brush off the 
competition of the Japanese Manga shows, which is by the way the correct 
term - Manga. Which is the Japanese equivalent for Comics. Manga as an art 
is said to target specifically at drawing realistic human PROPORTIONS. I 
say it in capitals for everyone who will accentuate on what I just said and 
try to opose me with "The titans don't have human proportions". Now when 
someone bases a cartoon on the story of a manga, IT IS STILL MANGA, just 
animated. And if one absolutely wants to use the term Anime, therefore DC, 
Marvel, or even Disney cartoons are Anime. Manga, not Anime. You're welcome.

comments.text:
This comment's got nothing to do with subs/dubs

I don't agree with your definition of Otaku,
Google definition of otaku is "(in Japan) a young person who is obsessed 
with computers or particular aspects of popular culture to the detriment of 
their social skills."

This is not Japan. This is not the USA. This is not the UK or Australia or 
wherever you are. This is the internet. Heck, I am in France but that does 
not mean squat on here, because even an American told me here on youtube 
"well this is America, welcome to America". Um no, it is not. I am not in 
America nor am I about to enter it. And I am an American btw

Words have their meaning for a reason. Otaku is a JAPANESE term. If you 
want to give it your own definition, you do so using another word no one 
else used before.
It's like if Japanese people started using the N-word and say "oh well this 
isn't America so it's fine it's not an insult" NO IT IS NOT TRUE.

The N-word has the same meaning ANYWHERE. Otaku has the same meaning 
EVERYWHERE. It's a derogatory term, used to define people that are usually 
shut-ins, socially awkward, or anti-social. Otaku does NOT mean "anime fan" 
or whatever unofficial definition whoever gave it.

Even the Urban dictionary definition for Otaku mentions how westerners 
confuse it for a positive word 
http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=otaku
It irks me to see people misuse a word that's not even native to your own 
language. Research a foreign word before using it..

Anyways this is it. I'm done, I wrote this beautiful essay that would make 
even an English teacher proud even if it's not 100% correct grammatically. 
Feel free to hate, ignore, comment, love, etc. I think argument is won, no 
need to comment actually.
comments.author: Midnight Snacks

comments.text:
+BlazinNSoul I really don't understand why everyone makes such a big fuss 
about "accurate translations." If they get the meaning across as it is 
supposed to, in a way a character would say it, but phrased in a way that 
sounds better in English and might even throw in a word or phrase not in 
the original script to even it out, what's wrong with that? I understand 
localization complaints, and unless it's a complete gag dub, like 
Shin-chan, I don't want them messing with the plot, but PHRASING? I just 
don't see the big deal. Localization doesn't sell well, Funimation and 
other serious dub makers know this, and so changes to script other than 
phrasing is minimal. And humor... as long as it's in character, I'm okay 
with them substituting jokes, because let's be honest, Japanese humor and 
American humor are very different, and what may be a witty riddle in 
Japanese and English subtitles will just sound clunky in spoken English.

Maybe this is just me, but I really don't care all that much. If 4kids was 
dubbing my favorite stuff, though... yeah, I'd be pretty mad.
comments.author: Julia Chi

comments.text:
+Julia Chi
Just giving a few examples not an entire list ya know.  Funimation has few 
good dubs but mostly they are nothing close to the original. Disney's 
handling of most Studio Ghibi films.

Most have been stellar but generally is not the case. If they focused more 
on getting the dubs accurate it would translate better.

I think this is done to keep up with the pace of the show, and often the 
humor. As well as the idioms, and other figures of speech tend to get lost 
in translation.

 I think it would give more weight to the project if done better. Watch a 
good subtitled track once. See how much it differs from the dubbed in many 
cases.

comments.text:
One reason why Dubbed sounds weird to Subbed people and why Subbed sounds 
weird to Dubbed people, is because you're really not used to hearing that 
character speak a certain way. Take your favorite show (outside of anime) 
and one day they changed the main character's voice, your first reaction 
would be "Wait... that doesn't sound right." it's the same idea here. Also, 
getting the new English lines to sync up with the mouths is actually really 
hard, if you watch interviews they have to watch the scene play to fit the 
words in, sometimes changing the line. Plus, literally translating the 
lines from Japanese (or any other language really) would not only not fit 
the way the characters speak, but also sound wrong to people that speak 
English. I have nothing against Subbed, just trying to shed some light on 
stuff! 
I personally think the voice acting in Attack on Titan is fantastic, they 
ALL give it their all and it sounds realistic at times, like with Eren's 
Mom. If you want bad Dubbed voice acting, watch Elfen Lied. It has some of 
the worst Dubbed acting I have ever heard (no offence fans of the show, but 
I really dislike that anime). If that's what all Dubbed sounded like I 
wouldn't blame Subbed people, but there are a lot of good animes that have 
awesome dubs. I think Fairy Tail, Hetalia, and Attack on Titan have 
fantastic dubs. That part is just my opinion though

comments.text:
Lets be fair here, sometimes the subbed versions aren't better. Baccano is 
the best example I could think of because the anime takes place in the 
United States(around the 1930's). Of course someone from the United States 
would do a better impression of someone living in that time period than a 
Japanese person, just like how an American's voice wouldn't fit a Japanese 
character very well. Most animes are based in Japan so I think that's 
partly the reason why they don't fit very well. It also has to do with 
casting and how Japan often has a lot more resources for anime than a 
dubbing company like Funimation. Oh and there's the fact that subs are 
often fanmade, so they never really have very translations. I remember 
reading all these Parasyte mangas/subs where they were still spelling 
Shinichi's name as "Shinji". Saying that a sub is better than a dub just 
because it's the original doesn't make much sense to me, I just pick from 
the voices I like better.

comments.text:
+Margaret Lor The anime is overrated, it has laughable attempts at drama, 
poor characterization, relies on shock factor and anticipation shock rather 
than methods of storytelling that don't break the fourth wall, it's not as 
serious as it pretends to be, pacing is all over the place, everything is 
over the top and still expects the audience to take it seriously, the 
characters are simple plot devices, and over all had terrible execution. 
The premise is also nothing special, it was done before back in 1999 by 
Blue Gender which is the same thing only more mature, and with well written 
characters. And no this is not because of taste, I was hyped for this show 
to, until I got to the filth episode and realized it just kept getting 
worse and worse.
